xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the website operator decides to send messages unencrypted, Google's servers may process it as plain text. Furthermore, potentially compromised or faked notifications might trick users into clicking on a malicious link.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Notifications

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications
, notifications will not be displayed for any sites and the user will not be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows access to connected USB devices from the browser

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a connected USB device
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Manage USB Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: WebUSB is opening the doors for sophisticated phishing attacks that could bypass hardware-based two-factor authentication devices (e.g. Yubikey devices).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select WebUSB API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access connected USB devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other USB devices) which could also prevent some two factor authentication (2FA) USB devices from working properly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow third-party partitioning to be enabled' in 'Third-party storage partitioning' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting will block specific sites your organization selects from accessing the storage session from any other site. This will allow an organization to block third party trackers that are embedded on multiple sites from tracking a user across the sites they visit. It will also allow blocking third party access to the user agent and to infer data about the user from the data from another site.

Setting the Level 2 recommendation Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled
will remove any sites listed in Allow third-party partitioning to be enabled
and block all sites.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If your organization does not want to block all third-party sites from accessing the user agent, you can configure a curated list of sites to block.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Third-party storage partitioning

Set Third-party storage partitioning
to to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This might cause the user experience to vary from allowed sites to blocked sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Third-party storage partitioning' Is Set to 'Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting will block any site from accessing the storage session from any other site. This will block third party trackers that are embedded on multiple sites from tracking a user across the sites they visit. Blocking third party access to the user agent will not allow sites to infer data about the user from the data from another site.
It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Enabled (1): Allow third-party storage partitioning to be enabled.
Disabled (2): Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents
Protect Dedicated Assessment Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this requires that user agent state needs to be keyed by more than a single origin or site. It can also defend against timing attacks on web privacy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Third-party storage partitioning

Set Configuration
to Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this may cause users to experience issues with sites they regularly visit that already grant access to third-parties.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Web Bluetooth API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows the access to nearby Bluetooth devices from the browser with users consent.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a nearby Bluetooth device
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Disable Wireless Peripheral Access of Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A malicious website could exploit a vulnerable Bluetooth device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Web Bluetooth API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access nearby Bluetooth devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other Bluetooth devices) and the user will never be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control use of insecure content exceptions' is set to 'Do not allow any site to load mixed content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Setting controls whether users can add exceptions to allow mixed content for specific sites.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to load mixed content
(2)

Allow users to add exceptions to allow mixed content
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the value of Do not allow any site to load mixed content
(2)

NOTE:
This policy can be overridden for specific URL patterns using the InsecureContentAllowedForUrls
and InsecureContentBlockedForUrls
policies.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Subscribe to URL-Categorization service

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing mixed (secure / insecure) content from a site can lead to malicious content being loaded. Mixed content occurs if the initial request is secure over HTTPS, but HTTPS and HTTP content is subsequently loaded to display the web page. HTTPS content is secure. HTTP content is insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Control use of insecure content exceptions

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to load mixed content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to mix content.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Sign-in settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing various aspects of how users interact with the Chrome browser within an organization.

Administrators can control how users interact with the Chrome browser on managed devices, including features like the new tab page, search settings, extensions, and even the visual appearance, to tailor the browsing experience for their organization's specific needs and security policies.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Download location prompt' is set to 'Ask the user where to save the file before downloading'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to download files automatically to the default download directory without prompting.
If this setting is enabled, users are always asked where to save each file before downloading.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from the drive-by-downloads threat.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Download location prompt

Set Configuration
to Ask the user where to save the file before downloading

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Browser guest mode' is set to 'Prevent guest browser logins'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user may utilize guest profiles in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In a guest profile, the browser doesn't import browsing data from existing profiles, and it deletes browsing data when all guest profiles are closed.

Deleting browser data will delete information that may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Browser guest mode

Set Configuration
to Prevent guest browser logins

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Guest mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Credit card form Autofill' is set to 'Never Autofill credit card forms'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved credit card information. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored credit card AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Credit card form Autofill

Set Configuration
to Never Autofill credit card forms

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, credit card AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Address form Autofill' is set to 'Never Autofill address forms'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved information such as address or phone number. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored address AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Address form Autofill

Set Configuration
to Never Autofill address forms

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow user feedback' is set to 'Do not allow user feedback'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are able to utilize the Chrome feedback feature to send feedback, suggestions, and surveys to Google, as well as issue reports.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Data should not be shared with third-party vendors in an enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow user feedback

Set Configuration
to Do not allow user feedback

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to send feedback to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'File selection dialogs' is set to 'Block file selection dialogs'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows access to local files by allowing file selection dialogs in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Allowlist Authorized Scripts
Integrate Software and Hardware Asset Inventories

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing users to import favorites, upload files, and save links could pose potential security risks by allowing data to be uploaded to external sites or by downloading malicious files. By not allowing the file selection dialog, the end-user will not be prompted for uploads/downloads, preventing data exfiltration and possible system infection by malware.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select File selection dialogs

Set Configuration
to Block file selection dialogs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will no longer be prompted when performing actions which would trigger a file selection dialog. Instead, the file selection dialog box assumes the user clicked "Cancel". Being as this is not the default behavior, impact to the user will be noticeable, and the user will not be able to upload and download files.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Google Translate' is set to 'Never offer translation'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google translation services on Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Content of internal web pages may be leaked to Google's translation service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Google Translate

Set Configuration
to Never offer translation

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After disabling this feature, the contents of a web page are no longer sent to Google for translation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Spell check service' is set to 'Disable the spell checking web service'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use Google web service to help resolve spelling errors.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information typed in may be leaked to Google's spellcheck web service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Spell check service

Set Configuration
to Disable the spell checking web service

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

After disabling this feature, Chrome no longer sends the entire contents of text fields to Google as you type them. Spell checking can still be performed using a downloaded dictionary. This setting only controls the usage of the online service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Network prediction' Is Set to 'Do not predict network actions'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome comes with the network prediction feature which provides DNS prefetching, TCP and SSL preconnection, and prerendering of web pages.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Predict network actions on any network connection
(0) or (1)

Do not predict network actions on any network connection
(2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not predict network actions on any network connection
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Opening connections to resources that may not be used could allow unneeded connections increasing attack surface and in some cases could lead to opening connections to resources which the user did not intend to utilize.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Network prediction

Set Configuration
to Do not predict network actions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be presented with web page predictions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Alternate error pages' is set to 'Never use alternate error pages'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to show suggestions for the page you were trying to reach when it is unable to connect to a web address such as 'Page Not Found'.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using navigation suggestions may leak information about the web site intended to be visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Alternate error pages

Set Configuration
to Never use alternate error pages

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, Chrome will no longer use a web service to help resolve navigation errors.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Payment methods' is set to 'Always tell websites that no payment methods are saved'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to set whether a website can check to see if the user has payment methods saved.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Saving payment information in Google Chrome could lead to sensitive data being leaked and used for non-legitimate purposes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Payment methods

Set Configuration
to Always tell websites that no payment methods are saved

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Websites will be unable to query whether payment information within Google Chrome is available.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Omnibox search provider settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing search options in Chrome browsers within an organization.

Administrators can control how user's interact with the onmibox in the Chrome browser on managed devices, including search suggestions, side panel configurations, history searches, and even what default search provider the browser will use.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Search suggest' is set to 'Never allow users to use Search Suggest'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers suggestions in Google Chrome's omnibox while a user is typing.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using search suggestions may leak information as soon as it is typed/pasted into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Search suggest

Set Configuration
to Never allow users to use Search Suggest

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The user has to send the search request actively by using the search button or hitting "Enter".

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Side Panel search' Is Set to 'Disable Side Panel search on all web pages'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the Google Search Side Panel. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable Google Search Side Panel on all web pages
Enabled (1): Enable Google Search Side Panel on all web pages

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will not allow the Google Search Side Panel on any webpages.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Side Panel search

Set Configuration
to Disable Side Panel search on all web pages

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no user impact.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Hardware settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for restricting or allowing specific hardware functions of Chrome browsers within an organization.
Administrators can control how hardware is accessed in Chrome browser on managed devices, including USB access, camera usage, and file system access.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enterprise Hardware Platform API' is set to 'Do not allow managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows extensions installed by enterprise policies to be allowed to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: It is recommended that this setting is disabled unless otherwise directed by Enterprise policies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Enterprise Hardware Platform API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Video input (camera)' is set to 'Disable camera input for websites and apps'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to video capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Turns off prompts and video capture will only work for URLs configured in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
list.

Enabled
(1): With the exception of URLs set in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
list, users get prompted for video capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all video input (not just the built-in camera).

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny video capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing video capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Video input (camera)

Set Configuration
to Disable camera input for websites and apps

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for video devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites which access will be allowed, configuration of the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Audio input (microphone)' is set to 'Disable audio input'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to audio capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Turns off prompts and audio capture will only work for URLs configured in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
list.

Enabled
(1): With the exception of URLs set in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
list, users get prompted for audio capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all audio input (not just the built-in microphone).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny audio capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing audio capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Audio input (microphone)

Set Configuration
to Disable audio input

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for audio devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites which access will be allowed, configuration of the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Sensors' is set to 'Do not allow any site to access sensors'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of system sensors such as motion and light.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Allow sites to access sensors
(1)

Do not allow any site to access sensors
(2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to access sensors
(2)

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to access sensors

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SensorsAllowedForUrls
and SensorsBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SensorsAllowedForUrls
can be used to allow sensor access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system sensors may prevent malicious sites from using these sensors for user profiling (OpSec).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Sensors

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to access sensors

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Web Serial API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of the system serial port.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a serial port
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API
(2)

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
, SerialAskForUrls
and SerialBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
can be used to allow serial port access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system serial ports may prevent malicious sites from using these ports and accessing the devices attached.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Web Serial API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome safe browsing settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing the level of protection users receive from potentially harmful websites, downloads, and extensions by enabling or disabling Google's Safe Browsing feature on Chrome browsers within an organization.
Administrators can control how users interact with safe browsing in the Chrome browser on managed devices, including:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Standard protection
- basic security against known threats

Enhanced protection
- provides more robust security by detecting potential new dangers but requires sharing more browsing data with Google

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: These features act as a safeguard against malware, phishing attempts, and other malicious online content by warning users before they access unsafe sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure no URLs Are Configured in 'Safe Browsing allowed domains'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The setting determines the functionality of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Safe Browsing protection applies to all resources

Enabled
(1), with a list of 1 or more sites: Means Safe Browsing will trust the domains you designate. It won't check them for dangerous resources such as phishing, malware, or unwanted software.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
Safe Browsing's download protection service won't check downloads hosted on these domains, and its password protection service won't check for password reuse.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or from downloading dangerous files.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing allowed domains
Remove any URLs from Allowed Domains

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE:
The only real impact is possible user annoyance if they are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This can be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/or notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing for trusted sources' is set to 'Perform Safe Browsing checks on all downloaded files'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can be adjusted to allow downloads without Safe Browsing checks when the requested file is from a trusted source. Trusted sources can be defined using recommendation 'Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings'.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
On Microsoft Windows, this functionality is only available on instances that are joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain, running on Windows 10 Pro, or enrolled in Chrome Browser Cloud Management.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information requested from trusted sources shall not be sent to Google's safe browsing servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing for trusted sources

Set Configuration
to Perform Safe Browsing checks on all downloaded files

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, files downloaded from intranet resources will not be checked by Google Services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings' is set to 'Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google provides the Safe Browsing service. It shows a warning page when users navigate to sites that are flagged as potentially malicious.

Disabled
(0): Users can choose to proceed to the flagged site after the warning appears.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious web pages are widely spread on the internet and pose the most significant threat to the user today. Users shall be prevented from navigating to potentially malicious web content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings

Set Configuration
to Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents users from proceeding anyway from the warning page to the malicious site. In some cases legitimate sites could be blocked and users would be prevented from accessing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Download restrictions' is set to 'Block malicious downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can block certain types of downloads, and won't let users bypass the security warnings, depending on the classification of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Block malicious downloads and dangerous file types.
(1)

Block malicious downloads, uncommon or unwanted downloads and dangerous file types.
(2)

Block all downloads.
(3)

Block malicious downloads. Recommended.
(4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Block malicious downloads. Recommended.
(4)

NOTE:
These restrictions apply to downloads triggered from webpage content, as well as the Download link... menu option. They don't apply to the download of the currently displayed page or to saving as PDF from the printing options.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Adequate Audit Log Storage
Ensure Backups Have At least One Non-Continuously Addressable Destination

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from downloading malicious file types, and shall not be able to bypass security warnings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Download restrictions

Set Configuration
to Block malicious downloads

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled, all downloads are allowed, except for those that carry Safe Browsing warnings. These are downloads that have been identified as risky or from a risky source by the Google Safe Browsing Global intelligence engine
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting prevents the display of lookalike URL warnings on the sites listed. These warnings are typically shown on sites that Google Chrome believes might be trying to spoof another site with which the user is familiar.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0) or set to an empty list: Warnings may appear on any site the user visits.

Enabled
(1) and set to one or more domains: No lookalike warnings pages will be shown when the user visits pages on that domain.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Look-alike domains are intentionally misleading to give users the false impression that theyre interacting with trusted brands, leading to significant reputation damage, financial losses, and data compromise for established enterprises.

In addition, this technique is commonly used to host phishing sites, and often leads to account takeover attacks. Users are prompted to enter their credentials on a fake website, and scammers take control of their online accounts with little effort to engage in fraudulent activity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains
Remove all URLs from Allowlisted Domains

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE:
The only real impact is possible user annoyance if they are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This can be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/or notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SafeSites URL filter' is set to 'Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use the Google Safe Search API to classify URLs as pornographic or not.
The recommended state for this setting is: Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select SafeSites URL filter

Set Configuration
to Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users' search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos, and images will not be shown.

NOTE:
Using Googles Safe Search API may leak information which is typed/pasted by mistake into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing protection' is set to 'Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode' and 'Allow higher-protection proxied lookups'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Control whether Google Chrome's Safe Browsing feature is enabled and the mode in which it operates. If you set this setting as mandatory, users cannot change or override the Safe Browsing setting in Google Chrome.
If this setting is left not set, Safe Browsing will operate in Standard Protection mode but users can change this setting.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
No Protection
(0): Safe Browsing is never active.

Standard Protection
(1): Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode.

Enhanced Protection
(2): Safe Browsing is active in the enhanced mode. This mode provides better security, but requires sharing more browsing information with Google.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode.
(1) or higher

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or from downloading dangerous files.
For more details, please refer to the items in the References section below.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing protection

Ensure Safe Browsing Protection Level
is set to Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode

Ensure Allow Safe Browsing's standard protection mode to send partial hashes of URLs to Google
is set to Allow higher-protection proxied lookups

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior (Standard Protection).

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Generative AI settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing various aspects of how users interact with AI features in the Chrome browser within an organization. This includes features like text generation, search enhancements, and comparison tools, enabling customization of the browsing experience to meet specific organizational needs and security policies.

The security recommendations provided are based on the assumption that an organization utilizes AI-powered products. A trust relationship with the technology vendor is essential, as sensitive data may be stored on their servers, similar to email and cloud storage. However, some features of the AI model also require the level of trust between customers of the AI model. If your data is used to train the AI model, then the other customers of the AI model can receive guidance that could be based on your organization's data. Enabling any AI feature(s) should be driven by organizational requirements.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended settings or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

Note:
Ensure proprietary data is not used for AI model training to prevent data leaks.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Generative AI policy defaults' Is Set to 'Allow GenAI features without improving AI models'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Generative AI policy defaults
sets the default options for all policies in the Generative AI
feature set if those setting are unset. This policy will be overridden for any settings that are set individually.

The Generative AI policy defaults
can only be set in the Google Admin Console and cannot be set locally.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended setting or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Setting a default baseline for all the settings in the Generative AI
section and will also encompass any new settings as they are added to the Google Admin Console. To find what features are currently available and set through the Generative AI policy defaults
you can visit the ChromeGenerative AI features and policies

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Generative AI
, select Generative AI policy defaults

Set Configuration
to Allow GenAI features without improving AI models

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
* For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is also achieved by setting Configuration
to Do not allow GenAI features
.
Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Help me write' Is Set to 'Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
Help me write
is an AI-based assistant that helps a user write web content, and is based on prompts entered by the user and the contents of the web page.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended setting or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Not allowing the Help me write
feature to improve the AI model's content can stop possible leakage of your organization's propriety information if it is used in the prompts to create the content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Generative AI
, select Help me write

Set Configuration
to Allow help me write without improving AI models
(or Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting
)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is also achieved by setting Configuration
to Do not allow help me write
.
Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DevTools AI features' Is Set to 'Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
DevTools AI features
is an AI-based assistant that provides additional debugging information. It requires the sending of error messages, stack traces, code snippets, network requests, and/or any other data collected for debugging purposes to Google to train the generative AI model. That data could include prompts, inputs, outputs, source materials, and written feedback, depending on the feature, and may also be reviewed by humans to improve AI models.

Note:
Response body or authentication and cookie headers in network requests are not included in the data sent to the server.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended setting or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Not allowing the DevTools AI features
feature to improve the AI model's content can stop possible leakage of your organization's propriety information of internal webs in the collected data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Generative AI
, select DevTools AI features

Set Configuration
to Allow DevTools Generative AI Features without improving AI models
(or Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting
)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is also achieved by setting Configuration
to Do not allow DevTools Generative AI Features
.
Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'History search settings' Is Set to 'Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
History search settings
is an AI-based assistant that helps search their browsing history and can receive generated answers based on page contents in addition to just page title and URL.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended setting or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Not allowing the History search settings
feature to improve the AI model's content can stop possible leakage of both your organization's propriety information through visited sites as well as any PPI from sites visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Generative AI
, select History search settings

Set Configuration
to Allow AI history search without improving AI models
(or Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting
)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is also achieved by setting Configuration
to Do not allow AI history search
.
Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Tab compare' Is Set to 'Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
Tab compare
is an AI-based tool for comparing product information across a user's tabs. This feature can be offered to the user when multiple tabs with products in a similar category are open.

Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is achieved by either implementing the recommended setting or disabling the feature(s) based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Not allowing the Tab compare
feature to improve the AI model's content can stop possible leakage of your organization's propriety information, or PII, if it is used.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Generative AI
, select Tab compare

Set Configuration
to Allow tab compare without improving AI models
(or Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting
)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
For compliance, adherence to security recommendations is also achieved by setting Configuration
to Do not allow tab compare
.
Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Help me read' Is Set to 'Use the value specified in the Generative AI policy defaults setting'

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Classify Service Providers
Establish Secure Configurations

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome update settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing full control of the update process for on Chrome browsers within an organization.

Administrators can control how and when Google Chrome browsers on managed devices receive updates, including specifying which update channel (Stable, Beta, Dev) to use, setting target versions, and determining whether updates are automatically applied or require manual intervention.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Component updates' is set to 'Enable updates for all components'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome's Component Updater updates several components of Google Chrome on a regular basis (applies only to Chrome browser components).

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

NOTE:
Updates to any component that does not contain executable code, does not significantly alter the behavior of the browser, or is critical for its security will not be disabled (E.g. certificate revocation lists and Safe Browsing data is updated regardless of this setting). FYI chrome://components
lists all components, but not if they are affected by this setting.

NOTE:
Google provided the following list of some of the components
controlled by this setting:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Recovery component
Pnacl
Floc
Optimization hints
SSL error assistant
CRL set
Origin trials
SW reporter
PKI metadata

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
To check the current components versions, navigate to chrome://components
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome Updater shall be used to keep the components bundled to Chrome up to date.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Component updates

Set Configuration
to Enable updates for all components

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Relaunch notification' sets 'Time Period (hours)' to '168 or less' and 'Initial quiet period (hours)' to less than 'Time Period (hours)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to set the time period, in milliseconds, over which users are notified that it must be relaunched to apply a pending update.

If not set, or Disabled
, the default period of 604800000 milliseconds (7 days) is used.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with value 86400000
(1 day)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is a notification for the end-user informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that said update takes effect as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure users restart the browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Relaunch notification

Set Time Period (hours)
to a value 168

Set Initial quiet period (hours)
to a value <
the value of Time Period (hours)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After this time period, the user will be repeatedly informed of the need for an update until a Browser restart is completed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Relaunch notification' is set to 'Show notification recommending relaunch'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can notify users that it must be restarted to apply a pending update. This setting controls how users are notified to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device to get the latest update.
The control can be set to one of three options:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: No relaunch notification: Activates a minimal default level of notifications. Chrome browser indicates to users that a relaunch is needed via subtle changes to its menu. In ChromeOS, a notification in the system tray prompts the user to relaunch.

Show notification recommending relaunch: Users see a recurring message that they should relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device. Users can close the notification and keep using the old version of Chrome browser or ChromeOS until they choose to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device.

Force relaunch after a period: Users can close the notification but will see a recurring message that they need to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device within a certain amount of time.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user will receive a notification informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that the update is applied as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure that users restart their browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Relaunch notification

Set Configuration
to Show notification recommending relaunch

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A recurring warning will be shown to the user indicating that a browser relaunch will be forced once the notification period passes. The user's session is restored after the relaunch of Google Chrome.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome variation settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing the rollout process to ensure stability and quality control on Chrome browsers within an organization.

Administrators can control how experimental features or updates are rolled out to users for Chrome browser on managed devices, enabling them to test new Chrome functionalities on a subset of users before a full release.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Variations' is set to 'Enable Chrome variations'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configuring this setting allows specifying which variations are allowed to be applied in Google Chrome. Variations provide a means for Google to offer modifications to Google Chrome without shipping a new version of the browser by selectively enabling or disabling already existing features.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Enable all variations
(0): Allows all variations to be applied to the browser (Default value).

Enable variations concerning critical fixes only
(1): Allows only variations considered critical security or stability fixes to be applied to Google Chrome.

Disable all variations
(2): Prevent all variations from being applied to the browser. Please note that this mode can potentially prevent the Google Chrome developers from providing critical security fixes in a timely manner and is thus not recommended.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enable all variations
(0)

NOTE:
Google strongly believes there is no added security benefit for turning this to critical fixes, as leaving it on increases the stability of the browser. Disabling variations can also prevent getting critical security updates in a timely manner.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google strongly recommends leaving this setting at the default (0 = Enable all variations), so fixes are gradually enabled (or if necessary, rapidly disabled) via the Chrome Variations framework.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Variations

Set Configuration
to Enable Chrome variations

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome variation settings are configuration options in the Google admin console for managing miscellaneous options that don't neatly fit into other categories on Chrome browsers within an organization.

Administrators can control various aspects of the Chrome browser experience not covered by standard settings like extensions, security, or user profiles, potentially including things like startup pages, search engine defaults, or specific feature toggles depending on the organization's needs.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Google time service' is set to 'Allow queries to a Google server to retrieve an accurate timestamp'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Chrome can send queries to a Google time service for accurate timestamps. This check helps in validation of certificates.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Standardize Time Synchronization
Utilize Three Synchronized Time Sources

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome uses a network time service to randomly track times from a trusted external service. This allows Google Chrome the ability for verification of a certificate's validity and is important for certificate validation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled
:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow queries to a Google time service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Google time service

Set Configuration
to Allow queries to a Google server to retrieve an accurate timestamp

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disk cache size in bytes' in 'Disk cache size' is set to `250609664'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the size of the cache, in bytes, used to store files on the disk.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled: 250609664
or greater

NOTE
The value specified in this setting isn't a hard boundary but rather a suggestion to the caching system; any value below a few megabytes is too small and will be rounded up to a reasonable minimum.

controls:safeguard.title: Securely Dispose of Data
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Having enough disk space for browser cache is important for a computer investigation and for investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts to be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Disk cache size

Set Disk cache size in bytes
to 250609664

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Browser cache will take up to 250MB in disk space.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Chrome Sync (ChromeOS)' is set to 'Allow Chrome Sync' and Exclude 'Passwords'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to specify data types that will be limited/excluded from uploading data to the Google Chrome synchronization service.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the following text value passwords
(Case Sensitive)

NOTE:
Other settings in addition to passwords
can be included based on organizational needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Explicitly Not Mapped
Explicitly Not Mapped

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Storing and sharing information could potentially expose sensitive information, including but not limited to user passwords and login information. Allowing this synchronization could also potentially allow an end user to pull corporate data that was synchronized into the cloud to a personal machine.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Chrome Sync (ChromeOS)

Set Configuration
to Allow Chrome Sync

Set List of types that should be excluded from synchronization
to Passwords

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Password data will not be synchronized with the Google Chrome synchronization service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Metrics reporting' is set to 'Do not send anonymous reports of usage and crash-related data to Google'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls anonymous reporting of usage and crash-related data about Google Chrome to Google.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
This setting is not available on Windows instances that are not joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Metrics reporting

Set Configuration
to Do not send anonymous reports of usage and crash-related data to Google

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, this information is not sent to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Chrome Sync and Roaming Profiles (Chrome Browser - Cloud Managed)' is set to 'Disallow Sync'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can synchronize browser data using Google-hosted synchronization services. Examples of synced data include, but are not limited to, history and favorites.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

NOTE:
if your organization allows synchronization of data with Google, then disabling this setting will synchronize saved passwords with Google.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser data shall not be synchronized into the Google Cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Chrome Sync and Roaming Profiles (Chrome Browser - Cloud Managed)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, browser data will no longer sync with Google across devices/platforms, allowing users to pick up where they left off.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow reporting of domain reliability related data' Is 'Never send domain reliability data to Google'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Never send domain reliability data to Google
Enabled (1): Domain Reliability data may be sent to Google depending on Chrome User Metrics (UMA) policy

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for DomainReliabilityAllowed
is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Use DNS Filtering Services
Maintain Inventory of Administrative Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled can stop any accidental data leakage.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow reporting of domain reliability related data

Set Configuration
to Never send domain reliability data to Google

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Prohibited Native Messaging hosts' in 'Native Messaging blocked hosts' is set to '*'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to specify which native messaging hosts should not be loaded.

Disabled
(0): Google Chrome will load all installed native messaging hosts.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of *

NOTE:
This needs to be handled carefully. If an extension is enabled, yet can't communicate with its backend code, it could behave in strange ways which results in helpdesk tickets + support load.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For consistency with Plugin and Extension policies, native messaging should be blocklisted by default, requiring explicit administrative approval of applications for allowlisting. An example of an application that uses native messaging is the 1Password password manager.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Native Messaging blocked hosts

Set Prohibited Native Messaging hosts
to *

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
A blocklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blocklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Background mode' is set to 'Disable background mode'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows for processes started while the browser is open to remain running once the browser has been closed. It also allows for background apps and the current browsing session to remain active after the browser has been closed.
With this setting Disabled, the browser will close its processes and will stop running background apps.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, vulnerable or malicious plugins, apps and processes can continue running even after Chrome has closed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Background mode

Set Configuration
to Disable background mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Apps & extensions is a high level configuration option in the Google admin console for more fine-tuned control for applications and extensions for the Google Chrome browsers within an organization.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'External extensions' is set to 'Block external extensions from being installed'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting blocks external extensions (an extension that is not installed from the Chrome Web Store) from being installed.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing users to install extensions from other locations (not the Chrome Web Store) can lead to malicious extensions being installed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings

Set External extensions
to Block external extensions from being installed

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
User will only be allowed to install extension for the Chrome web store.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allowed types of apps and extensions' is set to 'Extension', 'Hosted App', 'Chrome Packaged App', and 'Theme'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which app/extension types are allowed.

Disabled
(0): Results in no restrictions on the acceptable extension and app types.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the values of extension
, hosted_app
, platform_app
, theme
.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: App or extension types that could be misused or are deprecated shall no longer be installed.

NOTE:
Google has removed support for Chrome Apps which includes the types hosted_app and platform_app. The blog post indicates that these types will require a setting to be enabled for continued use through June 2022.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings

Set Allowed types of apps and extensions
to Extension
, Hosted App
, Chrome Packaged App
, and Theme

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Extensions already installed will be removed if its type is denylisted and the extension itself is not allowlisted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'App and extension install sources' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which extensions the users can NOT install. Extensions already installed will be removed if blocklisted.

Disabled
(0): then the user can install any extension in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of *

NOTE:
Chrome does offer a more granular permission-based configuration called Extension management settings
if blocklisting all extensions is too aggressive, which allows an organization to drill down to the exact permissions that they want to lock down. The extensions management settings require more coordination and effort to understand what the security requirements are to block site and device permissions globally as well as more IT management to deploy. The benefit would be allowing access to more extensions to their end-users. See link in reference section

NOTE:
If Chrome Cleanup is Disabled, users may want to configure the extension blocklist instead of using the Extension Management option. Chrome Cleanup can help protect against malicious extensions when paired with the Extension Management setting.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
This can be used to block extensions that could potentially allow remote control of the system through the browser. If there are extensions needed for securing the browser or for enterprise use, these can be enabled by configuring either the setting Configure extension installation allowlist
or the setting Extension management settings
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings
Remove all URLs from App and extension install sources

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Any installed extension will be removed unless it is specified on the extension allowlist. If an organization is using any approved password managers, ensure that the extension is added to the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Chrome Web Store unpublished extensions' Is Set to 'Disable unpublished extensions'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy disables any extensions in Google Chrome that were downloaded from the Chrome Web Store and are now unpublished. The policy can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Enabled (0): Allow unpublished extensions
Disabled (1): Disable unpublished extensions

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for ExtensionUnpublishedAvailability
is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is enabled.

Note:
Off-store extensions such as unpacked extensions installed using developer mode and extensions installed using the command-line switch are ignored. Force-installed extensions that are self-hosted are ignored. All version-pinned extensions are also ignored.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling unpublished extensions will remove the ability to run any extensions that are no longer being updated or patched.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings

Set Chrome Web Store unpublished extensions
to Disable unpublished extensions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may disable extensions commonly used by users in your organization.
